results.title: Song to Sing – Archie Roach
results.brief_description: Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for Wild Stallion Mountain (2015) clearly reflects that, playing like a mash-up of Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.
results.description: Strongly influenced by gospel in sound and style, ‘Song to Sing’ comes on the heels of Indigenous Australian musician Archie Roach suffering immense personal loss following the death of his partner two years earlier and his own health problems. The black and white video matches the uplifting rhythm of the track and features cameos from several prominent Australians including Roach himself, Jack Charles, Lou Bennett and Emma Donovan.
description_for_label: Strongly influenced by gospel in sound and style, ‘Song to Sing’ comes on the heels of Indigenous Australian musician Archie Roach suffering immense personal loss following the death of his partner two years earlier and his own health problems. The black and white video matches the uplifting rhythm of the track and features cameos from several prominent Australians including Roach himself, Jack Charles, Lou Bennett and Emma Donovan.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Pool Party – Julia Jacklin
results.brief_description: Intoxicated detachment is the mood most easily evoked in singer/songwriter Julia Jacklin’s music video for ‘Pool Party’ (2016). Featuring her drummer Tom Stephens as the co-star, it recalls a distinct 70s aesthetic with an Australian twist as it was filmed in Jacklin’s hometown, the Blue Mountains.
results.description: Intoxicated detachment is the mood most easily evoked in singer/songwriter Julia Jacklin’s music video for Pool Party (2016). Featuring her drummer Tom Stephens as the co-star, it calls to a distinct 70s aesthetic with an Australian twist as it was filmed in Jacklin’s birthplace, the Blue Mountains. As hypnotic as it is uncomfortable, it follows two characters as they struggle to meet in the middle visually, physically, and lyrically.
description_for_label: Intoxicated detachment is the mood most easily evoked in singer/songwriter Julia Jacklin’s music video for Pool Party (2016). Featuring her drummer Tom Stephens as the co-star, it calls to a distinct 70s aesthetic with an Australian twist as it was filmed in Jacklin’s birthplace, the Blue Mountains. As hypnotic as it is uncomfortable, it follows two characters as they struggle to meet in the middle visually, physically, and lyrically.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Treaty – Yothu Yindi
results.credit_line: ℗ 1991 Yothu Yindi (Yunupingu / Kellaway / Williams / Yunupingu / Mu)
results.brief_description: Montage is commonly used in music videos, yet in Yothu Yindi’s ‘Treaty’ (1991) it helped communicate the musicians’ disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics.
results.description: Montage is a common tool used in many music videos, yet in the case of Yothu Yindi’s song Treaty (1991) it helped communicate the musicians disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics. The spliced images became a political statement, with director Stephen Johnson making sure the micro-documentary was put it in a form where audiences who didn’t watch the news would see it.
description_for_label: Montage is a common tool used in many music videos, yet in the case of Yothu Yindi’s song Treaty (1991) it helped communicate the musicians disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics. The spliced images became a political statement, with director Stephen Johnson making sure the micro-documentary was put it in a form where audiences who didn’t watch the news would see it.
results.credit_line_for_label: ℗ 1991 Yothu Yindi (Yunupingu / Kellaway / Williams / Yunupingu / Mu)

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: My People – The Presets
results.brief_description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, ‘My People’ (2007) was one of the biggest hits of that year, propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes’s use of sci-fi aesthetics in the clip.

constellations_primary.name: My People
constellations_primary.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.

results.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets,’ My People’ was one of the biggest hits of that year and propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes. The sci-fi aesthetic of the clip and their sound directly influenced The Black Eyed Peas track ‘Boom Boom Pow’ after frontman will.i.am became a fan while exposed to The Presets music during the filming of in X-Men Origins: Wolverine in Sydney, Australia.
description_for_label: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets,’ My People’ was one of the biggest hits of that year and propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes. The sci-fi aesthetic of the clip and their sound directly influenced The Black Eyed Peas track ‘Boom Boom Pow’ after frontman will.i.am became a fan while exposed to The Presets music during the filming of in X-Men Origins: Wolverine in Sydney, Australia.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Since I Left You – The Avalanches
results.brief_description: Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling, The Avalanches’ ‘Since I Left You’ manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.

constellations_primary.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_primary.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

results.title_for_label: Since I Left You – The Avalanches [exhibition video]
results.description: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling from the Blue Source art collective, it manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.
description_for_label: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling from the Blue Source art collective, it manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Wild Stallion Mountain – The Bombay Royale
results.brief_description: Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for Wild Stallion Mountain (2015) clearly reflects that, playing like a mash-up of Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.

constellations_primary.name: Wild Stallion Mountain: Genre Mash-ups
constellations_primary.description: The Bombay Royale are known for combining funk, disco and pop with the sounds of classical Indian music together with the soundtracks of Bollywood cinema. Their music videos similarly hybridise  genres and styles to create intoxicating visual mash-ups.

results.title_for_label: Wild Stallion Mountain – The Bombay Royale [ exhibition video]
results.description: Wearing their influences firmly on their sleeve, Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for ‘Wild Stallion Mountain’ (2015) clearly reflects that. With both their sound and style linked very closely to movies, the music clip plays like a visual mash-up of their various inspirations including Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, the kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.
description_for_label: Wearing their influences firmly on their sleeve, Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for ‘Wild Stallion Mountain’ (2015) clearly reflects that. With both their sound and style linked very closely to movies, the music clip plays like a visual mash-up of their various inspirations including Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, the kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: The Children Came Back – Briggs and Geoffrey Gurrumul Yunupingu
results.credit_line: ℗ 2015 Warner Music Australia Pty Ltd. (Briggs / Yunupingu / McGregor / Roach)
results.title_for_label: The Children Came Back – Briggs and Geoffrey Gurrumul Yunupingu [exhibition video]
results.description: Briggs and Geoffrey Gurrumul Yunupingu’s “The Children Came Back” was released ahead of NAIDOC week in 2015. It speaks directly to Australia’s history of oppressive policies towards First Peoples, such as the forced removal of children from their families and assimilation. It’s an adaptation of “Took the Children Away” (1990) by Archie Roach and features varied traditional instrumentation like yidaki from North East Arnhem Land, vocals from the Tiwi Islands and clap sticks.
description_for_label: Briggs and Geoffrey Gurrumul Yunupingu’s “The Children Came Back” was released ahead of NAIDOC week in 2015. It speaks directly to Australia’s history of oppressive policies towards First Peoples, such as the forced removal of children from their families and assimilation. It’s an adaptation of “Took the Children Away” (1990) by Archie Roach and features varied traditional instrumentation like yidaki from North East Arnhem Land, vocals from the Tiwi Islands and clap sticks.
results.credit_line_for_label: ℗ 2015 Warner Music Australia Pty Ltd. (Briggs / Yunupingu / McGregor / Roach)

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: My Hometown – Munro Melano
results.brief_description: When he was just 17-years old, drummer Leon Isackson started capturing his life on the road from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown ‘ (2014).

constellations_primary.name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative
constellations_primary.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

results.description: Leon Isackson is considered one of Australia’s greatest drummers, having played with everyone from John Farnham to Johnny O’Keefe and Little Pattie. When he was just 17-years-old, he started capturing his life on the road as a touring musician for six years from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown’.
description_for_label: Leon Isackson is considered one of Australia’s greatest drummers, having played with everyone from John Farnham to Johnny O’Keefe and Little Pattie. When he was just 17-years-old, he started capturing his life on the road as a touring musician for six years from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown’.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Native Tongue – Mo’Ju
results.credit_line: ℗ 2018 Mojo Juju, exclusively licensed to Australian Broadcasting Corporation. (de Luzuriaga / Ma / Seumanutafa)
results.brief_description: Deceptively simple, Mo’Ju’s ‘Native Tongue’ it uses a single shot of the singer and three Djuki Mala dancers walking through an unmistakably Australian landscape. The glitch effect utilised not only adds visual emphasis to the on-screen movement, but also underlines the poignant lyrics.

constellations_primary.name: Native Tongue
constellations_primary.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

results.description: The lead single off their album of the same name, Native Tongue (2018) saw artist Mo’Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals. Deceptively simple, it uses a single shot of Mo’Ju and three Djuki Mala dancers walking through an unmistakably Australian landscape. The glitch effect utilised not only adds visual emphasis to the on-screen movement, but also underlines the poignant lyrics.
